title: Police release e-fit of man who fell to death from plane near Heathrow Airport
text:
Police have issued an e-fit of a man who fell to his death near Heathrow Airport

Police have issued an e-fit of a suspected stowaway who fell from the landing gear compartment of an aeroplane.

The man is believed to have plunged around 3,500ft before landing in a south London garden.

His frozen body hit the ground so hard it dented paving slabs and fake grass and narrowly missed a sunbather.

Four months after the tragedy, officers say they are still unable to identify the man.

He is believed to have been Kenyan and in his 30s.

Officers are still trying to find out who the man is who fell into a Clapham garden in June (Picture: Met Police)

Officers were called at 3.39pm on June 30 to a residential address in Offerton Road, Clapham.

Residents described hearing a ‘whomp’ as the frozen body hit the concrete.

A post mortem showed that he died from multiple injuries and his death is not being treated as suspicious.

The man was on a Kenyan Airways flight from Nairobi to Heathrow Airport.

Today officers from London’s Met Police released an e-fit as well as images of a bag that was found in the landing gear compartment.

The man is believed to have been carrying this bag, which was found in the aeroplane (Picture: Met Police)

The strap of the bag had the distinctive lettering ‘MCA’ written onto it, and the bag also contained a small amount of Kenyan currency.

The e-fit shows a logo on a top that the man had been wearing.

The man’s body is currently being held at a mortuary.

Once the investigation is complete, a file will be produced for the coroner and an inquest can take place.

These belongings were found in the plane (Picture: Met Police)

Detective Sergeant Paul Graves, of the South Central Command Unit, said: ‘We have pursued a number of lines of inquiry in what has been a very sad incident to investigate.

‘This man has a family somewhere who need to know what has happened to their loved one.

‘Our investigation has included liaison with the authorities in Kenya, from where the flight took off, but so far our efforts to identify this man have proved fruitless.

‘I hope by releasing this e-fit someone known to the deceased will recognise him and make contact.’

The letters MCA were found on the bag (Picture: Met Police)

In 2012, Jose Matada fell to his death from a British Airways flight inbound from Angola.

Advertisement

Advertisement

Mr Matada, originally from Mozambique, was found on the pavement in East Sheen on September 9.

An inquest into his death heard he is believed to have survived freezing temperatures of up to minus 60C for most of the 12-hour flight.

But he was understood to be ‘dead or nearly dead’ by the time he hit the ground.

In 2015, the body of a man landed on a shop in Richmond having clung on in the undercarriage of a plane from Johannesburg in South Africa to Heathrow.

Anyone who can assist the investigation into the Clapham death is asked to call police on 101 ref CAD 5395/30 June.
